comments.commentBody:
and Elke
Was looking for the EDITOR'S NOTE stating that after yesterday's big bean menu, we would need SPANDEX today (OK- speaking for myself ).
Great puzzle with some wonderful clues for I DO (another I word?), LOTTO, STL, CEASE FIRES and more.
Despite many names am not in a BAD MOOD, because I GOT both DANA and DANO .
HERE'S HOPING I could get some BEN and Jerry's here ; might as well DELIMIT that SPANDEX.......
CIAO.

Whenever I come to those DANO/DANA patterns, I usually hear Eric BANA knocking at the door. Also, unlike Johanna, I invariably get into an ORNE/ORLE flap.

I'm almost resigned to it.

It is certainly good that some of the Carrier jobs are staying in the US. But con man Donnie's Carrier deal was a failure compared to what he promised. Throughout the campaign, Trump promised to save all of the Carrier jobs by making clear that he would tax the heck out of the sale of Carrier's products in the US if they moved production overseas. Instead, Trump gave Carrier all kinds of tax giveaways and subsidies (and who knows what else) to a company that is moving 1,300 jobs to Mexico. And he's provided a roadmap for every other large corporation in the US to use their workers as pawns in an effort to extort the US for subsidies, tax giveaways, and other legislative favors. That's hardly the type of strong leadership that Trump pretend during the campaign that he would provide.

In 2009, faced with the possible collapse of the auto industry, President Obama took action and provided government loans (which were paid back) combined with restructuring plans, and thereby saved the US auto industry. Such action saved 1.5 million jobs in the US. In order to catch up to President Obama's record, con man Trump would just have to carry out a Carrier-style deal every week for the next 36 years. He could speed it up a little by producing Trump-branded merchandise in the US, rather than Vietnam and Mexico, and by using US steel in his buildings. But Trump has never cared about American workers, so he certainly won't do that.

https://www.facebook.com/WinningProgressive
Yes, how quickly President Obama's saving a major chunk of the auto industry is forgotten. Forgotten as well is the Republican outrage to his doing so.

So this is what it's come to: in place of the rule of law (contracts) or even the art of persuasion (consensus building), we'll have a president who thinks he can pressure employers into conforming to his will. Sounds like a protection racket to me: "We'll make it worth your while to run your business in ways that benefit both of us." Trump seems to think that he can bully the country the way he bullies everyone else. One can only hope that he's met his match. Who would have thought it: corporate America can strike a blow for freedom and good governance!

I cannot remember when or if a newly elected president-elect acted as if he were already president.  Is there substance here or is it a man who cannot help but make himself the center of attention?  Is this truly a good deal or just postponing the inevitable so that Mr. Trump can have another day in the sun?  I cannot help but wonder how Mr. Trump will take it if the next president-elect brokers deals as if he were already in the oval office.

I think the state government of Indiana will collect income tax from the income from each worker , of several thousand dollars per year per year, and each job also helps create other jobs in the area for merchants and services, and those workers also all pay income tax, and all the workers all pay local sales tax, etc, rather than being on unemployment, which the state government would have to pay. So, it looks like a very good deal compared to losing all of those jobs to Mexico,
and the $7000 per year per job is easily recovered for the state government

The carrots and sticks that Trump and Pence applied to Carrier is reminiscent of the corporatism that Il Duce (Benito Mussolini) imposed in Italy after he came to power in the early 1920s. It didn't augur well for Italy and it won't for the United States. Globalization and free trade require businesses, large and small, to make smart economic decisions, not clumsy, token political ones.

Politically, government pressure on business is at odds with traditional conservative values of limited government, individualism, and free markets. How Paul Ryan and other Republican leaders will react will be interesting to observe. Will it be an invasion of the body snatchers?

Yes, taxpayer money was used, but it was only Indiana taxpayer money. one of the big differences is that the auto bail out wad structured as a loan, which had since been paid back, while this is just good old-fashioned corporate welfare.

Obama saves 1.2 million auto manufacturing jobs, and he barely gets a thank you.

Trump "saves" 1000 jobs in Indiana and our dear leader is hailed as a visionary man of action. The reality is that Carrier just shook down the United States to the tune of $7 million. And there are some people celebrating this?

There won't be any manufacturing jobs left in the world in two decades, making Trump dictator isn't going to do anything to stop that.
The GM deal was a cramdown, not a save.
The Republicans would have let GM die simply because they have well paid union workers.  President Obama saved the US auto industry, after the Dubya administration tanked the economy...

Someone has posted on Twitter a letter to those Carrier employees; the letter was dated today and states that the manufacturing jobs are still going away. The engineering and administrative jobs are staying in Indiana, as was probably always the case. If that letter is legitimate,  the cons (and the Indiana taxpayers) have been conned. Is this the new normal - who can outcon who?

Having had a similar response for our car industry in Australia it is apparent how this goes. Every time there is a need for new investment the companies go to the government and threaten to shutdown if they don't get tariffs and/or government assistance. Then after another few years we still have the same problems and so they ask again. Eventually it is costing a ridiculous amount to keep them afloat, so the government assistance stops and they shut down.

It's not about losing. It's about understanding the sleigh of hand deal that will ultimately results to no long term solution. The devil is in the details. To ignore the details and to just blindly cheer a temporarily solution is completely naive. Trump is just using his playbook, his MO that landed him the White House.

Corporations wanted all the benefits of globalization and trade without having to assume the responsibilities, especially with displaced workers. They left that to the government. What is even worse is that we now have a globalization of labor where now companies have the right to threaten to move to lower wage countries, unless, like Carrier, they get subsidies to remain.

We were originally told by the "oligarchs" that free trade, especially with lower wage countries, i. e. TPP, would ultimately, raise their standard of living which would enable them to buy more of our goods. For the most part that never happened, in fact, over the last 30 yrs. wages have stagnated and thousands of companies have still moved offshore. An experienced auto worker in Mexico still only earns around $4.00 per hr. plus benefits and that has not increased much in recent yrs.

What guarantee is there that tax breaks will lead to greater employment in manufacturing? If I was running a manufacturing firm I would take my tax break and use that money to pay myself and upper management even more handsomely than before and continue on ahead with replacing what remains of my workforce with machines.

End result, I am richer than ever because not only do I not have to pay any workers, I now also do not have to pay any tax, either! Meanwhile my displaced workers have less of a safety net to look forward to now their jobs are gone because they foolishly voted for politicians that changed the tax code to get me and my corporation out of having to pay any tax to support them.

Trump and his cronies are truly running a masterpiece of a con on the plebs. Who says the Russians or the Chinese have the world's most diabolical oligarchs?

The so called best Mayor of the City of New York Michael Bloomberg give Goldman Sachs $250,000.000.00 in tax breaks for their headquaters in lower and to create and maintain jobs. Where are the jobs Goldman created. Cut out the negative comments. Compare to the hundreds of millions of dollars the liberal city gives to developers as incentives for housing or to maintain business and jobs that no one ever sees, seven million is less than peanuts.

So Trump is basically going to build a huge federal revenue stream of taxes to pay off companies to keep jobs in the United States? All while product costs to consumers inevitably skyrocket and he starts spending like a madman on infrastructure and a bloated military? What a disaster!

United Technologies lost its nerve when Trump won the Election because it realised it had billions tied up in government contracts, which dwarfed its air-conditioning business. In fear of reprisals, it sacrificed Carrier's wholesale plans to move to Mexico. A win for Trump.
If Carrier was so terrified of losing the contracts then why did they keep less than half the jobs and why did Trump have to give them money?  They don't look too terrified to me.

Deals like these are only a finger in the dike. I miss the days of hand-made buggy whips as much as anyone, but you can't prevent the future from arriving. As for your specific points:

First, the state of Indiana saved these jobs. Trump showed up to take credit.

Two, Trump didn't use taxpayer money. Pence used Indiana tax breaks, effectively raising taxes on everyone else in the state.

Three, the taxpayer money Obama used in the GM bailout was paid back with interest by GM. It also saved a million-plus jobs across the Rust Belt in the depths of the worst recession since the Depression, when losses of that magnitude would have been catastrophic.

Four, the loss of manufacturing jobs is now mostly due to technology. The best way to cope is not by demonizing offshoring, but rather with initiatives like the manufacturing innovation institutes described at manufacturing.gov. And with education and retraining and a subsidized transition period for affected workers, as Carrier was going to provide. Anything else is just playing for time.

Trump himself did nothing - Pence and Indiana gave the company enough tax incentives to keep *some* of those jobs in Indiana. Pence and the state could have done this themselves before the election.

Once again Trump gets someone else to pay for his big ideas and still takes all the credit. Once again his supporters, failing to see through all this, eat it up.

You seem to have forgotten that Trump never won the popular vote. Far more Americans approve of President Obama than of President-Elect Trump. No matter what the 1000 employees of Carrier may think today, there are millions of other disenfranchised voters who are waiting for their jobs to materialize. I wish Mr. Trump the best of luck with finding the billions of dollars it will take to bring those jobs back, even temporarily.

The Democratic Party and NYTimes continue to expose their blatant hypocrisy. They are blistering this Trump deal, which is simply a ten year $700,000/year incentive from Indiana to save 1,100 working class jobs. Where was the outcry when Democratic-led blue-state Connecticut Governor Dan Malloy gave the largest hedge fund in the world (Bridgewater) $22 million in an effort to keep it from moving its headquarters out of the state: http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/28/business/dealbook/biggest-hedge-fund-s...
The Democrats are fine with helping the elite Northeast billionaires and millionaires who are employed at Bridgewater in exclusive Fairfield County, Connecticut. But it is evil to incentivize a firm employing working class folks making $30-50 thousand/year in Indiana. They obviously have not learned anything from this election. It is exactly this hypocrisy from the Democratic Party and mainstream media that led to Trumps victory and this behavior will only continue to weaken the Democratic Party going forward.
The GOP was livid when Obama saved GM. Where is the real hypocrisy?
I just showed you real blatant hypocrisy and you failed to address it.

You do realize this is how ALL states do business?  How many tax breaks do you think car manufacturers get to build a plant in a specific state?  Louisiana gives tax incentives to oil and gas companies when they put a new plant in the state. Our movie industry, now known as Hollywood South, was built on tax breaks to the movie companies, because it literally employs thousands of people in the state.  Now Georgia is giving similar breaks.  I guess I just forget that liberals don't understand business and economics, all they understand is government handouts and safe spaces.
Its done in every state. Most states give tax breaks to entice companies to move in, or stay if they're already in.  The only difference here is the process is pushed along by the feds.

Donald Trump could add a few more American jobs if, for example, he stopped manufacturing his ties in foreign factories. After all,  there are American factories that are perfectly capable of producing his ties.  He will not, because he is a hypocrite,  a typical businessman who wants to pay as low a wage as possible in an effort to enhance his own financial bottom line.  It is pity that his followers will fall for this publicity stunt.

This reminds me of Juan and Evita Peron.  Pick and choose a few "saves" here and there with LOTS of media attention and attending chants of praise from the descamisados (the shirtless, the blue collar working class in this case) but it's a smoke screen for advancing self serving interests with greater financial, cultural and long term effects than most of us can imagine at this early stage of the game.  It would be pure and simple entertainment if there wasn't so much pain to come.

Critics of this deal should go to Indianapolis and explain to those workers whose jobs are saved that they are fools being cynically manipulated by Trump and that they would be far better off collecting unemployment insurance and getting retrained for jobs that, if they existed, won't pay as well.

Let us know how that turns out.
